pros:
- Might be a good place for you if you want to try different things

- Good place to learn how to and how not to manage people and projects

- Close contact with clients

- Strong push for women when hiring, promoting

- Push for gender parity. Easier career mobility and when staffing for roles for women compared to men these days, for those without connections/networks
cons:
- Training approver may persistently not approve your trainings, even if relevant to the business and work you do

- Work is getting mundane these days. Do not be lured by the fancy things Accenture says you will do during recruitment. Highly likely those fancy things/roles are very few and wont be done by you.

- Dumped onto projects which are usually not what we want to do or build on your expertise. No proper training before projects.

- Managers and Senior Managers remaining these days only know how to talk or go around in circles, and dump work on juniors, who may not even report to them.

- Hard to travel at junior levels as most projects are staffed locally.

- Difficult to transfer to the business unit which is a better fit for your skills. Business units can be exclusive and not truly cooperative.

They will train some of us like 1 wk or less than 4 days and throw u on the ground to answer calls or make out bound calls. LOL to that. - the pressure is on like ur a kid in a sch n not treated like an working adult. - the director of the inchrg project will walk arnd with hands behind her back and walk arnd like a principle to show u her presence. like ur supposed to be very afraid of em. - they're too free to keep auditing n interupting ur calls and reprimand u infront of everyone like u hv no dignity. - theyre super lack of staff. thats y they rush u to be on the ground thats what we all newbies feel. - u will feel very judged and demoralize, all of my trainees feel like dragging their feet to work every single day. - they shudnt even get this person to be the project manager, her body languange is so such a turn off. the TLs are way better than her. Very humble, bet she also donnoe what shes doing. you can tell la shes plastic la chasing the ladder tryna proove her worth where she stand n how she can lead the team given that she just newly got promoted. very AUTHORATIVE. - after yr few subjects of training youre given a test. theres too many subject to absorb in a day, and they dont gve u that ample time to read, understand better or even breathe. - tell off the poor trainer infront of us like he didnt do a good job when hes very supportive and better than her. - tbh everyone is suffocating and complaining abt this new manager and how she handles stuff and even how she react to it. very unprofessional. - we all have feedback to our respective hrs but yet no action taken. - they like to use this " we cant afford any mistakes" when their mistake was to put u on ground for less than 4 days training or even 2wks training with too much products to remember -.-

review_title: Good when good, really bad when bad
pros: Global reach, colleagues and expertise from international offices. Higher than average pay (but nothing that local banks won’t match). Learnings from having a plethora of clients.
cons:
Gaslighting from bosses is a norm in my operating group in Sg office (which is apparently a work place offence in Western countries). 

Competitive, no, cannibalistic as unrealistic pressures are put to deliver to client (10 hours per day) and sell or help sell (additional 3-4 hours a day, plus weekend).

Terrible hours, terrible work load. This is a place to pick up what you need to get and run away as soon as you can.

Tip for anyone that’s joining: there’s a high chance that you’re joining a team full of emotionally-challenged people. If you prioritise your mental health, join another team or transfer out of Financial Services to other operating groups (e.g. Resources, H&PS). Or just join a startup, since you’ve qualified to join Accenture already.

review_title: Great brand and proposition, but tricky to navigate
pros:
Coming from the perspective of a junior in the firm (working in Accenture as a first job after graduation):
- Decent benefits
- People at the working level are generally friendly and cooperative
- Great brand name
- Stakeholder management is something you get to develop early on in your career (dealing with difficult clients, demanding superiors)
cons:
Not mincing my words, here are my general observations:

- It is easy to feel lost in the firm as a junior without support/ mentors. You have to build your own network and pick up things on your own
- The outright focus on billing and chargeability for analysts means that more often than so you do not have a say/ flexibility over what you want to work on and end up getting stuck in certain roles/projects (defeating the purpose of joining consulting for a variety of experiences)
- The hype of recruitment on-campus is slightly overrated. If you're in Consulting, most of work you will be doing is less related to "VR experiences" or "Design Thinking" and more towards producing documentations (slides, word docs, excel sheets) and for the client More often than so you will be placed on projects with little to no context and be expected to deliver without much guidance i.e. "the relevant materials are in our SharePoint, go read them and talk to the client"; also in many cases there is less room for innovation as the clients already know what they want and expect us to execute their demands (generally the top-down nature of clients in Singapore)
- Partners/ Managing Directors as rainmakers are often silo-ed from the realities of struggles faced at the working level. Be it long working hours or demands from difficult clients taking a toll on your mental/physical health, lack of growth in current role, transparency on remuneration and promotion, everything ultimately boils down to sales - exaggerating the good side of things and overlooking the not-so-good. This is what results in many promising individuals leaving the firm for better opportunities
- Due to the gap between Leadership and the working level, mid-management (Senior Managers) can sometimes assume the mantle and belittle the working level on the basis of their somewhat unreasonable demands. This creates a culture of fear that is unnecessary and unproductive
- As with most MNCs, favoritism exists and promotion is not always made on the basis of capability, but visibility

review_title: Outdated business model riding on a dying brand name. Avoid government group at all costs!
pros:
Experience based on government projects, can't  speak for the others:

Some genuinely good people around. Learn what you can from them because they won't stay long.

Good introduction into legacy Enterprise IT. Feel the pain and understand why the industry has long moved on from these outdated"best practices"

Insight into how professional services firms generate profit. For e.g. churning at the lower levels, company lock in by not investing in training (mid-career guys get stuck, can't get a real technology job with PPT and excel as only skills), questionable business development practices.

Good company to grow in if you're interested in the commercial aspects of IT delivery and business development. Terrible place if you aspire to be a technology professional.
cons:
Singapore office acts as an independent entity, separate from global leadership. You'll constantly receive materials regarding global initiatives to develop the consulting workforce, but sadly, none are implemented in Singapore. Most people will be stuck doing low value delivery work throughout their career. Senior consulting folks will try to spin off their work as "delivery consulting", but can't write complete sentences without grammatical errors. Cool story bro.

Useless management consulting workforce due to a bad fit with the overall business. Not any fault of their own because they were sold a lie when joining the company. 

Can't claim transport even when traveling to remote data centres because you are given "Transport allowance".

Mediocrity at it's finest, colleagues with > 10 years of IT experience can't troubleshoot mounting a NFS share. High performance, delivered.

review_title: Good place to start your IT career
job_title: Business and Integration Arch Analyst in Singapore
pros:
- Amazing exposure to IT Enterprise Projects
- Can learn more about different technology stacks 
- Better understanding about the Technology Architectures for different projects
- Good Pay
cons: - Work-life balance very blurred

pros:
- Some smart people. 
- Good shared knowledge platform (knowledge exchange)
- Good learning opportunities for Singaporean and PR analysts.
- Office is conveniently located next to City Hall MRT station and close to lots of great restaurants and bars.
- Fantastic view of the CBD. 
- Free sodas and coffee.
- Access to many large regional corporates.
- Salary is on par with market.
cons:
Senior manager generally cares more about their own P&L than actual client needs. They will definitely try to push business to customers based on their recent experience.

- Silo mentality. Accenture Strategy, Accenture Management Consulting, Accenture Technology compete with each other for same clients. Same goes for senior management. 
- Huge amounts of time selling instead of delivering. 
- Staffing is based on pecking order and favoritism. No Godfather = no staffing. Also based on prior projects, so end up pigeon-holed and specializing on early projects. 
- Stingy expense policy, spartan office.
- Each country is quasi independent, except for Singapore that does some cross selling.
- Promotions are primarily based on politics. Eg. Banding processes is quite subjective 
- Singapore office mostly comprised by non-southeast Asian foreigners with limited knowledge (and local business connections) of the regional market. 
- Pretentious colleagues within Strategy division. Most Strategy people would refuse to talk to non strategy people.
- Deficient on-boarding process. Prior experience outside of consulting is not valued. 
- No systems in place to on board experienced hires and/or working parents. 
- Want to hire MBAs and yet don't value their experience. Very few MBAs overall. 
- Slower career path that other firms (eg. 3-5 years per role).
- Lack of strategy projects, most of staff on the bench. Some of strategy staff has never been staffed in strategy projects. 
- High attrition rates. ~30% per year

pros: Increasingly driving innovation to be world leaders across a broad range of technical and functional areas- you learn something new everyday, and will always be inspired by what we do in partnership with our clients. As an employer, ACCENTURE also innovates, never afraid to think big and be brave in talent management. Whether it's the People First philosophy or Performance Achievement, the company is pushing the boundaries in its own HR practices, in turn helping us be Authentic in our consulting. I've been with the company 12 years now, and have always felt empowered to do things my way, and have had the flexibility to shape the direction and pace of my career which has crossed everyone of our industry groups, allowed me to work in 9 different countries, while continuing to build expertise in my functional area.
cons: This company is big - 400k+, it takes effort to stay connected to the best of what we do, and pressure from clients to always bring the best of the best to the table can demanding. In the consulting world, the quality of people is very high, which is great, but means there is always pressure every year to improve your performance, deliver more, and grow the practice

review_title: Extremely customer centric, not employee centric, doesn't value new opinions, not flexible work culture
pros:
Excellent salary
Very Sophiscated
Excellent IT systems in place
Excellent technology in use
cons:
Doesn't believe in assigning correct work for employee specialization.
Pretty overstaffed - hence many people are on bench. 
People on bench are forced to take up roles that don't belong to their competency and continue in those roles for years due to organizational structure.
Very sophisticated look and work mechanisms - but bottom line very poor planning. 
Consultants / Staff are very pressurized due to HR and Snr Mgt mistakes of hiring the wrong competencies
No pressure /penalty on HR / Schedulers to place people onto roles quickly.
People are often fired (diplomatically managed out) due to them being on bench for a few months - thus totally spoiling their career. It is very difficult for them to find another job and to explain as to why they got fired.

New Joiners are left pretty clueless of the entire sophistication, if they get a career counsellor who is senior.

pros: In terms of location I was placed in Taguig. The place is well developed and the office is nice. However, note there are 5 locations in the Philippines. You may be placed in other branches
cons:
As a entry level, they will borderline abuse you. I was a Associate Software Engineer by title but worked as a SAP Consultant. Believe you me, the value of a SAP Consultant is 3-4 times my salary. But just cause I was entry level they didn't pay right.

2nd, management is bad. They don't recognize the people that actually performs rather they prioritize their favorites. I supported 2 softwarers,, 1 of which I am the sole support for. I was the top closer in our team and I was snubbed from being promoted. Not to mention, when I decided to resign they dangled that promotion to my face saying they will promote me. 

3rd, Toxic workplace. In this company I was part of the consulting department we we're required to work 9 hours a day. But in my project, we worked maybe borderline 11 hours. And since management doesn't want to explain our overtime to the client(which pays our salary) we dont get paid overtime.

4th, There are no windows in our office. Why? In order for you to lose track of time. 

If you still want to work here as a new grad. I don't know anymore what to say. I loathe this company. Say goodbye to life. Work life balance is NON EXISTENT
